articles.headline: Pills Tracked From Doctor to Patient to Aid Drug Marketing
articles.snippet: Vast databases of patient and doctor information being used by drug makers let them know which medications physicians are prescribing and how they compare to colleagues.
articles.abstract: Vast databases of patient and doctor information being used by drug makers let them know which medications physicians are prescribing and how they compare to colleagues.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the old days, sales representatives from drug companies would chat up local pharmacists to learn what drugs doctors were prescribing. Now such shoulder-rubbing is becoming a quaint memory — thanks to vast databases of patient and doctor information being used by pharmaceutical companies to market drugs.

articles.headline: Groups Press Big Retailers on Safety Overseas
articles.snippet: Two separate groups sent letters to Wal-Mart, Target, Sears and Gap, urging them to sign on to the factory safety plan that over 30 European retailers embraced this week.
articles.abstract: Two separate groups sent letters to Wal-Mart, Target, Sears and Gap, urging them to sign on to the factory safety plan that over 30 European retailers embraced this week.
articles.lead_paragraph: A large coalition of religious groups and investors is pressing major American retailers to join a sweeping plan to improve safety in Bangladesh apparel factories, calling on them to act together to force changes in overseas workplaces.

articles.headline: A Fine Line Between Social and Political
articles.snippet: Is tax law being widely flouted by political groups determined to avoid disclosure of their donors?
articles.abstract: Is tax law being widely flouted by political groups determined to avoid disclosure of their donors?
articles.lead_paragraph: As everyone from Republican senators to President Obama denounces the Internal Revenue Service for singling out Tea Party organizations for extra scrutiny, it is worth asking how we got to the point that the I.R.S. is supposed to investigate political activities. It is also worth asking whether the tax law is being widely flouted by political groups determined to avoid disclosure of their donors — and whether successive administrations have failed to enforce the law.

articles.headline: New Jersey Hospital Has Highest Billing Rates in the Nation
articles.snippet: The Bayonne Medical Center billed Medicare for common treatments at a rate more than four times the national average, according to a Times analysis of 2011 data.
articles.abstract: The Bayonne Medical Center billed Medicare for common treatments at a rate more than four times the national average, according to a Times analysis of 2011 data.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAYONNE, N.J. — The most expensive hospital in America is not set amid the swaying palm trees of Beverly Hills or the luxury townhouses of New York’s Upper East Side.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell, Barry Meier and Jo Craven McGinty

articles.headline: Syria Begins to Break Apart Under Pressure From War
articles.snippet: A constellation of armed groups battling to advance their own agendas is effectively creating the outlines of separate fiefs.
articles.abstract: A constellation of armed groups battling to advance their own agendas is effectively creating the outlines of separate fiefs.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAIRO — The black flag of jihad flies over much of northern Syria. In the center of the country, pro-government militias and Hezbollah fighters battle those who threaten their communities. In the northeast, the Kurds have effectively carved out an autonomous zone.

articles.headline: Aiming for the Top, Again
articles.snippet: Fred Eckert was once a star investor, but by 2011, he was bankrupt, divorced and had spent two months in a coma.
articles.abstract: Fred Eckert was once a star investor, but by 2011, he was bankrupt, divorced and had spent two months in a coma.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Wall Street, the wheel of fortune can spin around and around, from enormous cash bonuses and luxurious perks one year to the unemployment line the next.

articles.headline: Russia Sends More Advanced Missiles to Aid Assad in Syria
articles.snippet: Antiship cruise missiles could make it more difficult for the United States and its allies to impose a naval embargo, establish a no-fly zone or carry out airstrikes in support of Syria’s rebels.
articles.abstract: Antiship cruise missiles could make it more difficult for the United States and its allies to impose a naval embargo, establish a no-fly zone or carry out airstrikes in support of Syria’s rebels.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia has sent advanced antiship cruise missiles to Syria, a move that illustrates the depth of its support for the Syrian government led by President Bashar al-Assad, American officials said Thursday.
articles.byline: By Michael R. Gordon and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: G.O.P., Energized, Weighs How Far to Take Inquiries
articles.snippet: A crucial question for Republicans is how heavily they can press their cases against President Obama without provoking a backlash.
articles.abstract: A crucial question for Republicans is how heavily they can press their cases against President Obama without provoking a backlash.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The investigations ensnaring the White House have unified the Republican Party, energized a political base shattered by election losses and given common purpose to lawmakers divided over a legislative agenda.

articles.headline: Steve Jobs’s Widow Steps Onto Philanthropic Stage
articles.snippet: Laurene Powell Jobs has carefully entered the public sphere, pushing her agenda in education as well as global conservation, nutrition and immigration policy.
articles.abstract: Laurene Powell Jobs has carefully entered the public sphere, pushing her agenda in education as well as global conservation, nutrition and immigration policy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Marlene Castro knew the tall blonde woman only as Laurene, her mentor. They met every few weeks in a rough Silicon Valley neighborhood the year that Ms. Castro was applying to college, and they e-mailed often, bonding over conversations about Ms. Castro’s difficult childhood. Without Laurene’s help, Ms. Castro said, she might not have become the first person in her family to graduate from college.
articles.byline: By Peter Lattman and Claire Cain Miller
